advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It has not finished to surprise you"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (AUGUST 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Yannick Noah Tennis cartridge. The game is only called "Grand Slam Tennis" on the Emerson Arcadia 2001, but in France was marketed with the most famous french tennis player's name, Yannick Noah.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> T-1200 (DEC. 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The industry said it couldn't be done. You can't put a hard disk in a portable PC, make it powerful and keep it under 11 lbs.<br> Well, with this that challenge in mind, we immediately went to work to prove them wrong, presenting the result, the new T1200... </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>First Newburry brochure cover<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>"TO8D, the smart present"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Yoann Riou for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>January 1983<br><br> Telcon needed customers payments before manufacturing the systems:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Upon receipt of your check, we will forward an end-user agreement. Allow 6 to 8 weeks for delivery of the units. </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH PRICE LIST</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is a part of a complete French price list of the C64 and VIC-20, including peripherals, accessories and software.<br> You can download the <a href="http://www.old-computers.com/Museum/downloads/Commodore/FrPriceList.zip">complete version</a>.<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTOROLA AD.</strong></font><br><blockquote>In fact, this advert didn't promote the Macintosh II computer but the 68020 microprocessor.<br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...While Apple's choice of the MC 68020 was a smart move, there's no licence on genius: the 68020 is the microprocessor of choice in advanced business system design by such industry leaders as Altos, Alpha Micro, Casio, C.Itoh, Fujitsu, Honneywell Bull, NEC, NCR, Olivetti, Plexus, Ricoh, Sanyo, Sharp, TI, Toshiba and Unisys...</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert says:<br><br> <font color="#666666">The new ASC8000-6 single board computer is packed with ultra-high technology: Z80 double density computer, up to 2048Kb of high speed RAM, Floppy-disk and Winchester Hard Disk controllers, DMA, up to 6 serial / 2 parallel I/O, optional 32 bit floating point processor... All on one board, fully socketed, fully documented, reliable and maintainable...</font></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Right now, your computer for today"</blockquote>

computer.description:
In 1987 Canon USA Inc. released a new computer named the Canon Cat. This computer was targeted at low-level clerical workers such as secretaries. After six months on the market and with 20,000 units sold, Canon discontinued the Cat.
The Cat featured an innovative text based user interface that did not rely upon a mouse, icons, or graphics. The key person behind the Cat was Jef Raskin, an eclectic gadgeteer, who began the design of the Cat during his work on the first Macintosh project at Apple Computer in 1979.
The Cat was a 17 pound desktop computer system containing a built in 9" black-and-white bit-mapped monitor, a single 3.5-inch 256K floppy disk drive, and an IBM Selectric-style keyboard. It came with an extensive collection of applications stored in ROM. These applications supported word processing, spell checking, mail merging, calculator functions, communications, data retrieval, and programming in the FORTH or 68000 assembly languages. Also present in the ROM was a spelling dictionary based on the 90,000 word American Heritage Dictionary. System setup information and a small personal user dictionary were stored in 8K of battery backed up RAM.
The Cat's user interface made this computer unique. The user interface was based on a simple text editor in which all data was seen as a long stream of text broken into pages. Special keyboard keys allowed the user to invoke various functions. An extra key titled "Use Front" acted as a control key. You pressed Use Front and then a special key to activate a specific feature. For example, the L key was marked Disk, the J key was marked Print, and the N key was marked Explain (Cat's context sensitive help facility). Other commands existed to let you change the system's various parameters (Setup key) and reverse your last action (Undo key).
Contributors: David Patterson (editor), John J. Diamond (editor)
computer.keyboard: Monobloc system. Full-stroke keyboard (compatible with IBM Selectric), 49 keys. Special keys: LEAP (left & right), USE FRONT, DOCUMENT/PAGE, PERM SPACE/TAB, UNDO, ERASE, LOCK, SHIFT (x2)
computer.name: CAT
computer.ports: Centronics parallel port, RS-232C serial port (DB-25 connector), 2 x RJ-11 jacks (for telephone connections)
